name: Mixed Vegetable Pakora Baked
description: Broccoli, Cauliflower, potatoes, carrots and greens in this Mixed Vegetable Pakora. Baked Veggie Pakore Bhajjiya. Vegan Soyfree Recipe. Easily Glutenfree. I use all raw veggies in these as the veggies cook through easily if grated small. Makes 12 to 16 fritters

video.name: MIXED VEGETABLE PAKORA BAKED FRITTERS | Vegan Richa Recipes
video.description:
Broccoli, Cauliflower, Potatoes, Carrots, Greens in these Easy Baked Mixed Vegetable Pakoras. Easily GF.
FULL RECIPE: https://www.veganricha.com/2016/02/mixed-vegetable-pakora.html
MY BOOKS: https://veganricha.com/books

Veggie Pakore Bhajjiya or Bhajji. many names! These Baked pakoda fritters are great for breakfast, as appetizers, or use to fill up tacos or wraps or sandwiches.
They can be easily made gluten-free rice flour instead of semolina. 

These mixed Vegetable Pakora (bhajiya) are loaded with vegetables like broccoli, cauliflower, carrots, potato, onions and cilantro. The veggies are processed for a few seconds until grated, then tossed in chickpea flour, spices and baked. The pakoras are crisp and delicious and can be served with any green chutneys, tamarind date chutney or sauces of choice. They come together within minutes and then it is just a wait for the oven to beep. Make these simple Veggie and chickpea flour fritters!  Serve as is or fill up tacos or wraps, or over a salad with creamy or sweet dressing of choice, or use as koftas in a creamy makhani sauce.
Vegan Soyfree Nutfree Recipe

Music: Sunny Island by Scandinavianz

✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ ✧✦ 

Hi, I'm Richa! I create flavorful creative recipes that might need a tiny bit more work, but are totally worth it! Recipes generally include gluten-free, soy-free, and oil-free options. I also wrote 2 cookbooks! Vegan Richa's Indian Kitchen & Vegan Richa's Everyday Kitchen. Lets cook!

recipeIngredient: 1/2-3/4 cup broccoli florets, raw or steamed
1/3 cup chopped potato, raw or cooked
1/4 cup packed chopped cilantro or a small bunch
1/3 tsp ajwain (carom seeds or toasted cumin seeds)
1 tsp Chaat Masala or amchur (dry mango powder)
2 tbsp semolina flour (use brown rice flour to make gluten-free)

recipeInstructions.text: Chop the veggies roughly into similarly sized chunks or florets (1 to 1.5 inch). Add all the chopped vegetables, green chili, ginger, cilantro and mint in a food processor and pulse a few times to make a evenly finely chopped or grated state. You can also add a 1/3 cup or more greens of choice at this step.
recipeInstructions.name: Chop the veggies roughly into similarly sized chunks or florets (1 to 1.5 inch). Add all the chopped vegetables, green chili, ginger, cilantro and mint in a food processor and pulse a few times to make a evenly finely chopped or grated state. You can also add a 1/3 cup or more greens of choice at this step.

recipeInstructions.text: Transfer to a bowl. Mix in the spices, salt, 1/3 tsp chaat masala and semolina.
recipeInstructions.name: Transfer to a bowl. Mix in the spices, salt, 1/3 tsp chaat masala and semolina.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the chickpea flour to the bowl, sprinkle the baking soda all over and mix in (or mix the baking soda into the chickpea flour before adding). Add a tbsp or so more chickpea flour if needed. You need just a light coating of flour on all the veggies. See pictures above.
recipeInstructions.name: Add the chickpea flour to the bowl, sprinkle the baking soda all over and mix in (or mix the baking soda into the chickpea flour before adding). Add a tbsp or so more chickpea flour if needed. You need just a light coating of flour on all the veggies. See pictures above.

recipeInstructions.text: Let the mixture sit for 2-3 minutes so the veggies can leak some moisture into the flour. Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F / 220ºc.
recipeInstructions.name: Let the mixture sit for 2-3 minutes so the veggies can leak some moisture into the flour. Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F / 220ºc.

recipeInstructions.text: Add oil and a sprinkle of a water (1 -2 tsp) to the bowl and mix in. Depending on the vegetables, you might or might not need more water. The mixture should not be a batter, but should stick into balls with your hands. Add water a tsp at a time till the mixture just starts tot stick.
recipeInstructions.name: Add oil and a sprinkle of a water (1 -2 tsp) to the bowl and mix in. Depending on the vegetables, you might or might not need more water. The mixture should not be a batter, but should stick into balls with your hands. Add water a tsp at a time till the mixture just starts tot stick.

recipeInstructions.text: Using your hands or a tablespoon or ice cream scoop, place scoops on parchment lined baking sheet. Keep the scoops small, around 1.5 inches, so the veggies can cook through. Spray oil (or brush) on the pakoras.
recipeInstructions.name: Using your hands or a tablespoon or ice cream scoop, place scoops on parchment lined baking sheet. Keep the scoops small, around 1.5 inches, so the veggies can cook through. Spray oil (or brush) on the pakoras.

recipeInstructions.text: Bake for 22 to 25 minutes or until golden brown and crisp on the outside. Cool for a minute. Sprinkle the remaining chaat masala and serve with mint chutney or tamarind date chutney or ketchup or sauces of choice.
recipeInstructions.name: Bake for 22 to 25 minutes or until golden brown and crisp on the outside. Cool for a minute. Sprinkle the remaining chaat masala and serve with mint chutney or tamarind date chutney or ketchup or sauces of choice.
